document.docTitle: Litoblatta argentina Rocha e Silva Albuquerque & Aguiar 1975
document.masterDocTitle: Four new species of Litoblatta from Argentina with a key to species based on males (Blattaria: Ectobiidae: Blattellinae)

Male .
Measurements in mm. N= 117. PL : 3.00‾4.93; TeL: 10.30‾21.27; TL: 16.00‾24.89; IO : 0.60‾1.10; IOc: 0.40‾1.00; IA: 0.60‾1.10. Eyes shape: Males eyes are bigger and less separated than the eyes of females and with their ventral shape rounded ( Fig. 44 ). Supra anal plate posterior border slightly concave ( Fig. 34 ). Male right paraproct with a digital process, presents short conical spines on the internal basal margin ( Figs. 35–36 ). Right stylus with conical short spines and the left stylus without spines ( Figs. 37–38 ). Genitalia as described for the genus ( Figs. 39–42 ). R1 P ends distally as an expanded quadrangular area that includes the inner convex scale zone sz placed as in figures 40 and 43. The Holotype genital sclerites is shown in figure 43.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 34‒43 .
Litoblatta argentina
. 34. Supra anal plate apical margin slightly concave, dorsal view. 35–36. Right paraproct with a digital process and short conical spines on the internal basal margin, dorsal and ventral view. 37. Subgenital plate with styli, ventral view. 38. Detail of the right stylus with spines and left stylus pilous, ventral view. 39. Subgenital plate and genital sclerites, dorsal view. 40. Right complex R, dorsal view. 41. L2+via, dorsal view. 42. L3, dorsal view. 43. Photograph of the type specimen, genital sclerites (MNRJ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks .
Litoblatta argentina
is the only species found in the province of Río Negro . One female found mating in the locality of Sierra Grande ( Fig. 44 ). The couple was collected in an arid habitat as it can be observed in figure 45. There are other females that were collected carrying an ootheca ( Figs. 46–47 ) in the locality of Viedma. Darker and stouter than males ( Fig. 44 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 44‒51 .
Litoblatta argentina
. 44. Opposed position of a copulating pair, female brachypterous and male macropterous. 45. Habitat, Sierra Grande, province of Río Negro. 46–47. Oothecae. 48. Male mature nymph, dorsal view. 49. Female mature nymph, dorsal view. 50. Male nymph subgenital plate with styli, ventral view. 51. Female nymph subgenital plate and cerci, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
In the catalogues Crespo & Valverde 2008 and
Crespo et al. 2010
all the specimens of the institutions were misidentified following the currently used characters as
L. brasiliensis
, now identified as
L. argentina
, except for the new species herein described.
Distribution . Argentina-Provinces of Buenos Aires , Catamarca , Chubut , Córdoba , Jujuy , La Pampa , La Rioja , Mendoza , Neuquén , Río Negro , Salta y Tucumán
